main: ^Hey Rumyooo, have you ever heard of when block coding started?
^No, I haven't. When did it start exactly?
^Block coding started gaining popularity in the early 2000s as a way to make programming more accessible to non-technical users.
^The idea was to use visual blocks that could be snapped together to create programs,
^rather than requiring users to write code from scratch.
^This made programming more accessible and less intimidating to those who were new to it.
^That's interesting. Who were some of the pioneers in block coding?
^One of the earliest examples of block coding is Scratch, which was developed by the Lifelong Kindergarten Group at MIT Media Lab.
^Scratch is still widely used today and has inspired many other block-based programming languages such as this game, Gizmos and Language.
^Another popular block coding platform is Blockly, which was developed by Google and is used in a number of educational and commercial applications.
^You're welcome, Rumyooo! Block coding has come a long way since its early days,
^and it continues to evolve and become even more accessible and user-friendly.
